task: research term usage (p96 gars me grue)
notes: Resolved “It gars me grue” as a Scots idiom meaning “it makes me shudder” using Webster 1913 (gar=make) and Chambers 1908 (grue=shudder); updated p96 notes, quotes index, and research queue.

Identified “Holy Mr. Herbert” as LIKELY George Herbert (EB1911) / Marjorie Bowen’s “Holy Mr. Herbert” (Harper’s Magazine, May 1910); split remaining Haddock/Meed sub-item in research queue and updated p95 notes, people index, and quotes index.
Resolved p95 Leda/Hebe as mythic wordplay framing inking a Swan fountain pen; updated p95 notes, quotes index, objects/motifs, and research queue.
Resolved “turning a Somerset” as a variant spelling of “somersault” (Webster 1913); updated p96 notes and quotes index, and split/updated the related research-queue item (leaving Jifjaffa open).

Resolved p96 “Golden Tips” as tea-leaf tips (“the essence of the leaf”) using Henry W. Cave (1905), and split the remaining Loganberry Kiss/Plover’s Lunch menu research into its own open queue item; updated p96 notes, quotes index, and research queue.

Clarified p95 “Holy Mr. Herbert” via Walton’s Complete Angler and advanced p96 Loganberry Kiss/Plover’s Lunch grounding; updated page notes and relevant indexes and marked related research-queue items in-progress.

Resolved p96 Jifjaffa as Jifjafa (Sinai Range) via Gullett (1923) and traced p91 “see any green” / p92 “caddis-hoard” to period sources; updated page notes, places index, quotes index, and research queue.
Resolved p1 whaups quote as Stevenson and p3 Whitman quotations; identified Hodder & Stoughton as the implied publisher; updated page notes, quotes index, and research queue.
Resolved Masefield “Captain Stratton’s Fancy” rum quote (p23–p24) and identified Latham chapel as Selby Abbey (p68); updated relevant indexes and closed queue items.
Identified the Page 8/Page 19 knob as a service call-bell and Mr. Hall as the summoned servant; updated notes and indices and closed the queue item.

Identified the Page 19 queen quotation as Wotton’s “You meaner Beauties of the Night” (Queen of Bohemia) and grounded Falkland as Elizabeth Stuart’s birthplace; updated indexes and closed the queue item.
Resolved Page 22 De Witt allusion (John/Cornelius de Witt) and recorded the likely date anchor (24 Sept 1625) in notes and indexes.
Resolved Page 21 digitalis/Calabar bean terms via EB1911 and updated page notes, objects/motifs index, and research queue.
Updated p22 De Witt birthday interpretation to Cornelius (imprisoned brother) and cited a ≤1934 source for Cornelius’s birthdate; updated notes, places, and research queue.
Identified Page 20\x27s “oldest brass in England” inscription as Sir John d’Aubernoun at Stoke d’Abernon church (Surrey) and updated notes, places, objects/motifs, and the research queue.
Identified Page 20\x27s “Underneath this stone… as much Beauty as could die” as Ben Jonson\x27s epitaph “On Elizabeth L. H.” and updated page notes, quotes index, and the research queue.
Identified the Page 21 Adriatic/Illyrian hills quotation as Matthew Arnold’s “Empedocles on Etna” and updated page notes and indexes.
Confirmed Page 24\x27s “fourteen popes and two anti-popes” wording via EB1911 “Clement” and updated notes, people index, and the research queue.
Resolved Page 24 Ahkoond of Swat and Page 23 match allusions and Blackwood/left-luggage items; updated notes and indexes.
Clarified Page 22 de Witt birthday, resolved Page 25 song/date hook + Didling place, and resolved Page 26 Ben Wade pipe + bear-with-a-sore-head idiom.
Resolved Page 27\x27s “county town on the Severn” as likely Shrewsbury (EB1911) and updated notes plus indices.
Identified Page 28\x27s quoted lines as Oscar Wilde’s *The Importance of Being Earnest* (Act I, Lane) and resolved the related book/edition research items.
Resolved Page 29 plant/poison references (lobelia, lords and ladies, broad beans) and treated the 'old mineralogist' as an in-world placeholder (P35).
Identified Page 30’s quote probes as William Watson (“The Sovereign Poet”) and Robert Louis Stevenson’s *Underwoods* poem “Henry James”, and updated notes, quotes index, and research queue.
Resolved Page 31’s Caseus/Cassius pun and interpreted the rill/corncrake duet as vehicle/engine sounds; no unique external match found for the ‘awful night in Paris’ reference.
Identified Page 33 quoted letter as Lady Mary Wortley Montagu and interpreted black pineapple bits as loose tobacco; updated notes and indexes.
Identified Page 35’s Richard/Thomas line as a Shakespeare/Dryden quote-mash and treated Wellington Crisp as an in-world pastiche figure; updated notes and indexes.
Reviewed markdown docs and drafted Skill improvement suggestions; no repo changes beyond time log.
Identified Page 36’s good-uncle line as Tennyson’s “The Sisters” and confirmed old Calabar as Calabar bean/physostigma; updated notes and indexes.
